author: alpha_beta_pruning
body:
Semis can be risky/volatile since they're affected by trade policy and the market performance of other sectors, but that also makes them a great long term investment. TSM has some of the best fabs in the world. You might also check 
MCHP, AMAT, or NXPI. Or check out LRCX since they build the hardware that then builds your hardware. :)

author: BuyLowSellNever
body:
The companies that you want to purchase in this space are unlikely to be trading at below $5 a share, so this might be the wrong sub.


5G is high growth, high tech, which means high expectations on future earnings. The companies that jump to mind will be in the semiconductor space; AMAT and QCOMM.

author: PM_YOUR_VOLVO_TO_ME
body:
The list is pretty long so let me see what I can remember.

* $AAL
* $AKAM
* $AMAT
* $AMD
* AVGO
* $BA
* $CAR
* $CARR
* $CLX
* $DOW
* $DRI
* $DIN
* $DPZ
* $HON
* $INTC
* $JBLU
* $LUV
* $MSFT
* $NOK
* $NVDA
* $PFE
* $PLAY
* $QCOM
* $RTX (whatever raytheons new ticker is.)
* $SAVE
* $SLB
* $TSMC
* $UAL

Im pretty sure I'm missing some symbols but that's the majority of them.

The balance on this account at the February peak was about $130,000 in vanguard ETFs, after the first major slide I decided to move $80,000 to cash and the total value was $99k ish? Currently it just crossed back over the $100k mark

Once I found out the fed was going to pump the market I started dipping my toes into value/growth stocks that took a beating like amd, Pfizer, SLB, nvda, avgo and msft. I want to say around mid April is when I bought almost everything else with some exceptions which I think CAR was the last addition.

As for my tastyworks account, I've just been selling put spreads on most of the stocks on that list above the down days, cashing out on the up days and riding the volatility waves. I'm averaging a 50-65% return which is roughly netting me about 2-5% per week. 

If you have any other questions feel free to ask.

author: JhoLow1MDB
body: $AMAT.  They currently have a record amount of orders for next quarter, and a record backlog of orders that will be filled.  They are a critical backbone for many other bigger companies, such as TSMC, Intel, etc.  There is only going to be an increase for demand for their products with everything from 5G, cloud computing, AI, and quantum computing needing more high quality materials to make equipment for those purposes. TSMC literally is planning to build a factory in Arizona now because there were threats they'd get caught off from critical supplies from companies like $AMAT. The best part is that AMAT isn't insanely overpriced right now like so much tech.  You can still get it for a decent price.

author: caks
body:
Quick question regarding managing risks/profits. I bought OTM calls for AMAT expiring 10 July a couple weeks back. It's been OTM pretty much the whole time since then, become ITM today. If I sell at market price, I stand to make around 35% profit.

My question is, how to people decide whether to stick to an option until expiry or sell it before? As in, what kind of indicators should I look at in order to decide?

For sake of discussion, [here are the profit graphs for today and expiry](https://imgur.com/tcDEW6x).

Another thing I've started doing is looking at % change in OI, particularly decreases in OI, as that might indicate people writing the options are buying them back

Like SNAP 23.5c 7/2 saw a decrease of almost 10% in OI, I assume call writers buying them back

author: gizamo
body:
Lmfao. You're an idiot. All semis tool manufactures and chip providers are still selling to China. There are very few companies affect by that "ban" (which was a bipartisan bill lead by Democrats after investigations started by the Obama administration, lol). Further, AMAT, LRCX, and MU, and others have had exemptions the whole time.     
      
China owns Taiwan, numbnuts. Taiwan is China, anything done in or by Taiwan is an action China can exploit.     
      
TSMC building a fab in the US is a good thing, and had the TTP passed, it would have happened ages ago. But, an even better thing would have been any US company building that fab. That didn't happen because Trump/GOP are too dumb to see that semis are the future of military dominance. China gets that; it's why they are blatantly stealing everyone's tech and subsidizing the ever-living shit out of their semis industry.     
       
Foxconn moving into India is also bad, dumbass, because it means that's not a US company gaining market share there either. It's further expansion of CCP's ability to steal more tech.     
       
Also, yes, mining is a huge issue that Trump has also failed to solve in the US. In fact, his tariffs have hurt mining companies by significantly increasing their costs while also cutting away a massive chunk of their buyers. Lol. You are a massive idiot who clearly doesn't know shit about any of this. Lmfao, you election trolls are so dumb it's truly amazing.
